text:
(1)
350 to 342 West Houston Street, western section (formerly Hammersley Street), at and adjoining the north corner of West Street.
May 12, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
342 to 350 West Houston Street, the same scene viewed from the east, two years later. Everything in this westernmost block of West Houston Street will be demolished in 1930, and the street later closed.
March 8, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
West Street, east side, north from No. 346, north of West Houston Street (formerly Hammersly Street), opposite Pier 39, North River.
October 25, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, four years later, after the buildings north to Clarkson Street have been cleared away for the site of the New York Central & Hudson River Railroad's new St. John's Park Freight Terminal. Both of these pictures show the boys on horseback who rode ahead of trains on Tenth Avenue and West Street before the building of the elevated roadbed along the west side of Washington Street (q.v.).
January 18, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
West Street, east side, north from No. 346, north of West Houston Street (formerly Hammersly Street), opposite Pier 39, North River.
October 25, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, four years later, after the buildings north to Clarkson Street have been cleared away for the site of the New York Central & Hudson River Railroad's new St. John's Park Freight Terminal. Both of these pictures show the boys on horseback who rode ahead of trains on Tenth Avenue and West Street before the building of the elevated roadbed along the west side of Washington Street (q.v.).
January 18, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

Doherty's Hotel, 342 West Street at the S. E. corner of West Houston Street (formerly Hammersley Street), opposite Pier 39, North River. Adjoining the hotel used to be the Church of the Holy Comforter on the Houston Street side, and the Seamen's Church Institute at 341-340 West Street. The hotel itself will have to go in 1930.

October 25, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

340, 341 West Street, adjoining the S.E. corner of Houston Street (opposite Pier 39, North River). This is part of the site of the future new St. John's Park Freight Terminal.
March 6, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
West Street, east side, from West Houston Street (formerly Hammersley Street), opposite Pier 39, North River, to Leroy Street, opposite Pier 41. The lunch room on the corner at the right was supposed to have been in the hands of one family for a hundred years.
Hammersley Street (it was absorbed in 1858 by Houston Street, and lost its own name) was, prior to the redistricting of 1917, the south boundary of the Ninth Ward, which was roughly identical with "Greenwich Village."
October 25, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, a year and a half later, and including one or two buildings north of Leroy Street.
March 6, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) West Street, East Side from Leroy and Clarkson Streets, looking South. At the South East corner of Leroy Street is the new depot of the Monarch Freight System.

May 7th, 1942.

P.L. Sperr,

(1)
West Street, east side, from West Houston Street (formerly Hammersley Street), opposite Pier 39, North River, to Leroy Street, opposite Pier 41. The lunch room on the corner at the right was supposed to have been in the hands of one family for a hundred years.
Hammersley Street (it was absorbed in 1858 by Houston Street, and lost its own name) was, prior to the redistricting of 1917, the south boundary of the Ninth Ward, which was roughly identical with "Greenwich Village."

May 7th, 1942.

P.L. Sperr,

(1)

Hammersley Street (it was absorbed in 1858 by Houston Street, and lost its own name) was, prior to the redistricting of 1917, the south boundary of the Ninth Ward, which was roughly identical with "Greenwich Village."

West Street, east side, from No. 346, north of West Houston Street (Pier 39, North River), to No. 365, north of Leroy Street (Pier 41). October 25, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

Houston Street (formerly Hammersley Street), east from and including West Street. Hammersley Street was one of the group of parallel east-west streets laid out in the Trinity Church Farm, and met the western end of the original Houston Street just east across the line between the Trinity Farm and the West Bayard Farm, at the southern end of Bedford Street (q.v.).

In 1858 this street lost its own name and was absorbed by Houston Street. At that time, and thereafter till the redistricting of 1917, it served as the southern boundary of the Ninth Ward, which was roughly identical with Greenwich Village.

In 1930 these buildings at and east of West Street will be demolished for the site of the new St. John's Park Freight Terminal (see West Street). Houston Street, from West to Washington Streets, will be permanently closed and incorporated with the site of the freight station.

March 6, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Houston Street (formerly Hammersley Street), south side, from West Street towards Greenwich Street. The Church of the Holy Comforter used to stand at No. 345-341, where the billboards now hide the vacant lot; it was taken down less than eight years before the date of this picture.
June 3, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, a view all the way to Greenwich Street, three months later after the West to Washington Street block has been cleared, showing the east side of Washington Street, and, in the background, the new Standard Statistics Building under construction on the west side of Hudson Street, from King to Charlton Streets.
September 30, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Houston Street (formerly Hammersley Street), south side, from West Street towards Greenwich Street. The Church of the Holy Comforter used to stand at No. 345-341, where the billboards now hide the vacant lot; it was taken down less than eight years before the date of this picture.

(2)

September 30, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

West Street, east side, from West Houston Street (formerly Hammersley Street), opposite Pier 39, North River, to Charlton Street, opposite Pier 37. Demolition of buildings, for the site of the new St. John's Park Terminal, is going on.
September 30, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

West Street at the N.E. corner of West Houston Street (formerly Hammersly Street), opposite Pier 39, North River. June 3, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.
